content:
Hi,

Just wondering, for the case where the initial deposit is too low and as such the r value will never cause the amount saved to meet the break condition of the while loop, is it ok to say something like:

"If you have had more than 20 guesses (i.e. if steps>20), exit the loop and set r=None etc."?

I realise this is an arbitrary value, so I wondered if I should implement another break condition instead. I thought about doing something that compares the difference in successive guesses and if this difference meets a specific tolerance, then exit, but I realised that setting the value of tol/steps at which to break are essentially the same thing.

Thanks.
subject: PSET 1 Part C) query

content: Well, mathematically speaking, how would you know if it’s impossible for a certain R parameter to never get you to your goal in the set time? You shouldn’t need to break after a number of steps.
Ah ok - I guess I could analytically define the maximum value of amount_saved (using r=1) and if this value is < required amount, then break?
Yup! You may not even need to break if you know it ahead of time too.
Makes sense- thanks a lot for the help.
